entry.title: many body parts (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a human toe used for cocktails (pictured) is one of many body parts that are tourist attractions?

entry.title: a novel about Madagascar's colonization (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a novel about Madagascar's colonization, which the author was aware was impossible to publish under colonial rule, was finally published decades after his suicide?

entry.title: 73 Yards (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that working broadcast journalists were used as extras for the portions of the Doctor Who episode "73 Yards" that were filmed at the BBC Cymru Wales New Broadcasting House?

entry.title: Beijing Watermelon (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that plans to shoot the Beijing-set portions of the 1989 Japanese film Beijing Watermelon on location were cancelled after the Tiananmen Square protests and massacre occurred mid-production?

entry.title: Radcliffe Telescope (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Radcliffe Telescope was the largest telescope in the Southern Hemisphere when it was completed in 1948?

entry.title: Parengyodontium album (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the marine fungal species Parengyodontium album only breaks down polyethylene plastics that have been exposed to ultraviolet light?

entry.title: a biography of John D. Rockefeller (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that author Ron Chernow was reluctant to write a biography of John D. Rockefeller until being shown a 1,700-page transcript of three years' worth of private interviews with him?

entry.title: defeated a team of all-stars (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Green Bay Packers once defeated a team of all-stars chosen from the rest of the league?

entry.title: Adama Touré (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that on February 3, 1986, African Independence Party leaders Adama Touré and Adama Touré were released from detention?
